title: 111_s1520
content: CHAPTER 1504 - NATIONAL AMERICAN INDIAN VETERANS, INCORPORATED: This section recognizes National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated as a corporation and grants them a federal charter under Part B of subtitle II of title 36, United States Code. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is a federally chartered nonprofit corporation with purposes that include upholding and defending the Constitution of the United States while respecting the sovereignty of American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian Nations. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated aims to unite American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans, advocate for their needs, promote social welfare, and support research on their relationship with the United States. The National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated aims to unite American Indian, Alaska Native, and Native Hawaiian veterans, advocate for their needs, promote social welfare, support research on their relationship with the United States, provide technical assistance to regional areas without veterans committees, and establish membership eligibility and board of directors guidelines. The board of directors and officers of the corporation are determined by the constitution, bylaws, and laws of the jurisdiction. Membership and leadership roles in the corporation cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, handicap, or age. The corporation's powers are limited to those granted in its articles of incorporation, constitution, and bylaws, in accordance with the laws of the jurisdiction. The corporation, as per its articles of incorporation and constitution, has limited powers granted by the jurisdiction's laws. It has the exclusive right to use specific names, seals, emblems, and badges. The corporation is restricted from issuing stock, paying dividends, or distributing income or assets to members, officers, or directors during its charter's duration. The corporation is prohibited from distributing income or assets to members, officers, or directors during its charter. Reasonable compensation and reimbursement for expenses are allowed. Loans to any officer, director, member, or employee are not permitted. The corporation cannot claim congressional approval for its activities. It must maintain its tax-exempt status and keep accurate financial records. The corporation must maintain tax-exempt status as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It is required to keep accurate financial records, including books, minutes of proceedings, and member information. Members with voting rights can inspect records for valid reasons. The corporation must comply with the laws of its incorporating jurisdiction and where it operates within the United States and its territories. The corporation must comply with laws of its incorporating jurisdiction and where it operates within the United States and its territories. It is liable for acts of officers and agents within their authority. Failure to comply may result in charter expiration. Annual reports are required. The corporation must comply with laws and may face charter expiration if it fails to do so. Annual reports detailing activities must be submitted to Congress annually. National American Indian Veterans, Incorporated is referenced as "1504" in the context of complying with laws and submitting annual reports to Congress.
